lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to a story and identify key characters, times, and daily activities mentioned.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Say: “Listen for go to bed, have lunch, and 6:30.” Play the story. Students clap when they hear the target language.
stretchStrategies: Students create a new dialogue or comic strip where the main character changes their routine (e.g., wakes up late and misses school). They must write speech bubbles using the target time and activity language.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read the story aloud, act it out, and answer questions using the target language.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Assign roles and read the story together. Students act out each part using realia (e.g., small bag for “go to school”).
stretchStrategies: Students create a new dialogue or comic strip where the main character changes their routine (e.g., wakes up late and misses school). They must write speech bubbles using the target time and activity language.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can create a simple, imaginative ending to the story by drawing or acting it out.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Creativity) Show the last frame of the story. Ask: “What happens next?” Students draw or act out a new ending with 1–2 sentences.
stretchStrategies: Students create a new dialogue or comic strip where the main character changes their routine (e.g., wakes up late and misses school). They must write speech bubbles using the target time and activity language.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)
A wide variety of syllabus hobbies may be less popular or available to some Vietnamese students (practising the flute; seeing famous paintings), although many overlap

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
